publisher.publisher-name: Association for Research in Vision and Ophthalmology

subj-group.subject: Invited Session V: Binocular vision and interactions

title-group.article-title: Invited Session V: Binocular vision and interactions: Depth perception in virtual environments: The role of experience

aff.institution: Centre for Vision Research, York University

license.license-p: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-NoDerivatives 4.0 International License.

abstract.p: In this presentation I’ll review results of stereoacuity, disparity matching and depth magnitude estimation studies in which comparison of so-called naïve and experienced observers shows substantive differences in performance. I will describe our working theory that the critical difference between these groups is their tolerance to conflicts between stereopsis and other sources of depth information. Further, I will review some recent data that suggest there are some conflicts that even experienced 3D participants cannot disregard.

fn.p: Funding: Funding: Natural Science and Engineering Council of Canada
